description: Inherited from Middle English scourge, from Anglo-Norman scorge, escorge, escourge, escurge, from Anglo-Norman escorger (“to whip”), from Vulgar Latin *excorrigiō, from Latin ex- (“thoroughly”) + corrigia (“thong, whip”).

entries.meaning: A source of persistent trouble such as pestilence that causes pain and suffering or widespread destruction.
examples: Graffiti is the scourge of building owners everywhere.

definitionGroups.group: A means to inflict such pain or destruction.

entries.meaning: A whip, often of leather and often multi-tailed.
examples: He flogged him with a scourge.

description: Inherited from Middle English scourgen, from the noun (see above).

verbs.description: scourge (third-person singular simple present scourges, present participle scourging, simple past and past participle scourged)

entries.meaning: To strike with a scourge; to flog.
